nodes.text: The relative interference between word-reading and color-naming reflects differences in associative strength built by training, and practice can modify these interference effects
Background: Prior literature shows associative inhibition and habit interference across tasks (nonsense syllables, card sorting, animal habits, color naming vs word reading)

Method: Constructed stimuli combining a color word and an ink color (no word printed in its own color) and parallel control stimuli (words in black, color squares) to measure mutual interference; reaction time for 100 items used as measure
Experiment 1 method: Compared reading color names printed in conflicting ink-colors (RCNd) versus same names printed in black (RCNb); 70 undergraduates, counterbalanced forms, timed readings

Experiment 2 method: Compared naming ink-colors of words printed in conflicting colors (NCWd) versus naming colors presented as colored squares (NC); 100 students, counterbalanced, errors penalized by adding time
Experiment 3 method: Practice study with 32 subjects performing repeated NCWd trials over days to measure practice effects on NCWd, NC, and RCNd tests and on group variability
Result (Exp 1): Conflicting ink-color stimuli caused a small, nonreliable increase in time for reading words: mean increase = 2.3 seconds per 100 items (approx 5.6%), not statistically reliable

Result (Exp 2): Conflicting word stimuli produced a large and reliable interference on naming colors: mean NC = 63.3s vs NCWd = 110.3s for 100 items, an increase of 47.0s (74%), highly reliable (several SD units)
Result (Exp 3 practice on NCWd): Eight days of practice on NCWd reduced but did not eliminate the interference; NCWd mean dropped by 16.8s (33.9%); transfer to NC produced smaller gain (4.0s, 13.9%)

Result (Exp 3 variability and transfer): Practice on NCWd increased group variability on NCWd, increased interference of colors on reading (RCNd) and practice on NCWd produced large loss in speed on RCNd; one day practice on RCNd quickly restored performance
Claim: Associations linking word stimuli to reading responses are stronger (more effective) than associations linking color stimuli to naming responses, accounting for asymmetry in interference

Claim: Practice selectively modifies interference: strengthening the weaker color-naming association via practice reduces word-to-color interference, but practice also increases individual differences and can strengthen opposing interference effects on other tasks
Evidence: Quantitative measures showing small nonreliable color->word effect (2.3s) vs large reliable word->color effect (47.0s) and practice gains/losses summarized across experiments

Interpretation: Difference in interference corresponds to differential past training: the word-reading response is a highly trained, specific habit, whereas color stimuli elicit varied response tendencies

Conclusion: The observed asymmetry of interference and its modulation by practice support the hypothesis that training-built associative strength determines interference in serial verbal reactions; sex differences in color naming likely reflect differential training
